notes: Sharp regression discontinuity design studying the effect of need-based grants (BCS - bourses sur criteres sociaux) on college enrollment in France. Uses income-based eligibility cutoffs with local linear regression (LLR) and optimal bandwidth selection (Imbens-Kalyanaraman style via rdob). Multiple cutoffs for different grant levels: L0/No grant (0_X), L1/L0 (1_0), and L6-to-L1 (6_1). Running variable is inc_distance (negative of income distance from cutoff, so higher = poorer = more likely eligible). The main results are in Tables 3-5.

design_audit.notes: The running variable is -inc_distance (income distance negated so that crossing 0 from below means becoming eligible). rd_llr calls rdob_m which implements local linear regression with optimal bandwidth. Three cutoff samples: 0_X (no grant vs any grant, bw=0.20), 1_0 (L1 vs L0, bw=0.16), 6_1 (higher levels, bw=0.06). Each uses pooled 2008-2010 data.

claim_object.treatment_concept: Eligibility for a need-based grant (BCS) at the income cutoff
claim_object.estimand_concept: Sharp RD estimate: discontinuity in college enrollment probability at the grant eligibility income threshold
claim_object.target_population: French higher education applicants near the BCS income eligibility cutoff, 2008-2010

baseline_specs.label: Table3-LLR-0_X
baseline_specs.notes: rd_llr col_enrol with sample_0_X (no grant vs any grant cutoff). Optimal bandwidth ~0.20. Local linear regression.

baseline_specs.label: Table3-LLR-1_0
baseline_specs.notes: rd_llr col_enrol with sample_1_0 (L1 vs L0 cutoff). Optimal bandwidth ~0.16.

baseline_specs.label: Table3-LLR-6_1
baseline_specs.notes: rd_llr col_enrol with sample_6_1 (higher grant levels). Optimal bandwidth ~0.06.

constraints.notes: The baseline RD specifications use no covariates (pure local linear regression). The RD is non-parametric (no control variables). Covariates could be added as precision controls but the paper does not do this.

canonical.notes: Conventional LLR standard errors from rdob (Imbens-Kalyanaraman). No clustering.

variants.notes: Cluster at discrete income levels (if income has mass points).

budgets.notes: No controls to vary. Main axes: 3 cutoffs x (bandwidth, polynomial, kernel, procedure variants) + 13 sample restrictions + donut. Budget covers: 3 baselines + ~7 design variants x 3 cutoffs + ~13 sample restrictions.

sampling.notes: Full enumeration feasible. The specification space is naturally defined by cutoff x design choices x sample restrictions.

diagnostics_plan.notes: Test for manipulation of income at the grant eligibility cutoff (Table 2 in the paper tests balance).
Test whether observable characteristics are continuous at the cutoff.
